title: Level 10 Statistics Practice Test
description: Test your understanding of standard deviation, normal distribution, conditional probability, sampling, and expected value.

questions.question: If data is normally distributed, approximately what percentage falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean?
questions.explanation: The 68-95-99.7 rule states that approximately 68% of normally distributed data falls within $\mu \pm \sigma$.

questions.question: Which sampling method divides the population into subgroups and samples proportionally from each?
questions.explanation: Stratified sampling divides the population into strata (subgroups) and selects a proportional number from each, ensuring all groups are represented.

questions.question: In a class of 40, 24 study French, 20 study Spanish, and 10 study both. What is $P(\text{French}|\text{Spanish})$?
A data set has a mean of 50 and a standard deviation of 0. What can we conclude?

options.text: There is exactly one data point

questions.explanation: A standard deviation of 0 means there is no spread â€” every value in the data set is exactly equal to the mean (50).

questions.question: A game costs $\$3$ to play. You win $\$10$ with probability $\frac{1}{4}$ and nothing otherwise. What is the expected profit per game?
Heights of students are normally distributed with $\mu = 165$ cm and $\sigma = 8$ cm. What range contains approximately 95% of students?
questions.explanation: $\mu \pm 2\sigma = 165 \pm 16$, giving 149 to 181 cm. The 95% range covers $\mu - 2\sigma$ to $\mu + 2\sigma$.

questions.question: Calculate the variance of the data set: $2, 4, 6, 8, 10$. (Variance is the square of the standard deviation.)
A fair coin is flipped twice. Given that at least one head occurs, what is the probability that both are heads? Give your answer as a fraction.
questions.explanation: Sample space with at least one head: $\{HH, HT, TH\}$ (3 outcomes). Both heads: $\{HH\}$ (1 outcome). $P = \frac{1}{3}$.

questions.question: A school has 200 Year 7, 150 Year 8, and 100 Year 9 students. In a stratified sample of 90, how many Year 8 students should be selected?
A die is rolled. You win $\$6$ for rolling a 6 and lose $\$1$ for any other result. What is the expected value per roll? Give your answer as a fraction of a dollar.
